awd_titl_txt: Exploring STEM Career Pathway Persistence Among Student Service Members and Veterans: A Mixed Methods Study of Social Support Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

Student military service members and veterans, who are undergraduate students, face numerous medical, financial and social obstacles that universities and communities must address to prevent this skilled talent pool from leaving STEM before entering, or re-entering, our nation's workforce. For example, many service members and veterans have family or work responsibilities that limit full-time enrollment in post-secondary education. With the appropriate academic and social support systems, veterans and service members can succeed in college and advance their careers. It is critical for our nation to better understand the needs of this unique population and the social support networks that contribute to persistence in STEM. Advancing a diverse and technically competent STEM workforce is critical for contributing to the progress of science and the health, prosperity and welfare of our nation. 

The project team is exploring the association between social support networks and persistence in undergraduate STEM education among student military service members and veterans. More specifically, knowledge is being advanced about trajectories and social support characteristics of veterans and student military service members, as well as about the network variables associated with persistence along STEM academic and workforce pathways. This mixed methods research includes collecting and analyzing survey and interview data. Results are being examined to advance knowledge about why STEM undergraduate students, who are military service members or veterans, persist in STEM. Study findings will also provide university and college administrators and educators with information about how their institutions might better provide social, academic, health and career support services to advance the persistence and career paths of STEM veteran and military service members who are undergraduate students at their schools. 

This research is supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development. The program supports the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to understand, build theory to explain, and suggest intervention and innovations to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning and participation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Analysts contend that the U.S. STEM workforce suffers from a lack of adequately trained and diverse professionals. While reforms aim to improve persistence as students move through college STEM programs into STEM careers, little research has investigated the STEM career pathways of college student military service members and veterans, a group poised to expand and diversify the scientific workforce through their increased college attendance, advanced skills, and diverse backgrounds.

This three-year University of Wisconsin-Madison project addressed the influence of social support networks on persistence along STEM career pathways among student military service members and veterans. The three-year mixed methods study focused on students in five Wisconsin 4-year universities and utilized a cutting edge multiphase, panel design based on social network analysis.

Study data and analyses, which confirm and extend previous research, have thus far been used to publish one peer reviewed article, 12 data reports, and four research briefs as well as present findings to scholars and veteran services practitioners nationally. What implications, however, do findings have for those hoping to better support these students? Here are four insights from the work.

1. Revitalize university STEM student service member and veteran support and connection after COVID.

Findings suggest that the pandemic turned typical college social strengths into liabilities. Time 1 research showed that STEM student service member and veteran relationships with other college students associated with increased belonging and academic integration. In the pandemic’s wake, however, Time 2 respondents with higher proportions of Time 1 student ties reported more negative COVID-related impacts. Those who more often used their colleges’ student veteran lounges at Time 1 also reported more negative impacts from the pandemic. As helpful as these relationships can be in normal times, results indicate that those STEM students who were supported in college by fellow students and educators felt the sting of campus closures more than others.

2. Focus on dependable, professional, and authentic SSM/V services.

Study interviews show that student service members and veterans going through college STEM programs, many of whom already have numerous responsibilities off campus, are inundated with information and demands in an often unfamiliar social and cultural environment. They also come to the university from an institution in which structure, respect, professionalism, and common purpose mark daily interactions. For this reason, they often appreciate straightforward, informed, and trustworthy support focused on the numerous bureaucratic processes that help them attend university. Further, while they may not ask for it, interviewees suggested it was important for service professionals to offer moral support though encouragement, understanding their perspectives and experiences, and having their back during difficult moments.

3. Accentuate STEM student service member and veteran academic- and career-related drive and success.

The student service members and veterans in STEM we surveyed showed significant strength in the face of challenges through 2020, 2021, and 2022. Eighty-six percent of those surveyed had either continued in college or graduated and successfully pursued graduate studies or careers between Time 1 and Time 2. Findings also suggest that specific STEM student service member and veteran characteristics—even some that often lead to feelings of marginalization in college—correlated with positive outcomes. Older student service members and veterans, for example, had higher GPAs, while first-generation student service members and veterans were more likely to have better weathered the pandemic. Student service members and veterans in STEM also spoke to the myriad benefits that come with military experience, including public service orientation, communication skill, and time on the job.

4. Build on the unique value and diversity of STEM student service member and veteran social support networks.

Findings show rich variation across STEM student service member and veteran networks. They also point to the costs and benefits of different social support characteristics depending on one’s stage in life and STEM trajectory. In general, larger networks were consistently helpful to STEM respondents across varying life stages after college, as were ties with fellow veterans/service members. Tighter, denser networks, however, associated both with higher job satisfaction among workers and decreased academic performance among students. Respondents across all groups with family connections had more confidence in their career prospects, but workers with more family ties reported lower salaries.

5. Increase budgetary support for student service member and veteran services.

Carrying out many of the specific recommendations of our study focused on better supporting student service members and veterans in STEM fields would require higher educational institutions to increase their budgetary support for campus veteran service staff and their centers.

While results thus far are significant, the study team will continue analyzing the Time 1 and Time 2 data they have developed from their work in Wisconsin and plans to carry on with their dissemination of new knowledge about the nature of student service member and veteran experiences, trajectories, and success in STEM fields.


Last Modified: 12/06/2023
Modified by: Ross J Benbow
